What is a Ping?

What is a Ping?

Last edited: January 25, 2025

A ping is a tiny resonant message from the universe.

9:15am  •  Monday, July 22, 2024
Learning is the future
Ping 188 of 322  •  Laurel Schwulst

What a ping might mean, and how/if you might utilize it, is rarely clear in the moment.

9:15am  •  Monday, July 22, 2024
Learning is the future
Ping 188 of 322  •  Laurel Schwulst

In this way, you can think of a Ping as a place to start from, and the metadata that accompanies each one, as a tool to help you find your way back when you’re open to reflect on the meaning that might exist within it.

*

Each ping typically has three parts:

  1. Time & Date
    acknowledging the particular moment in time the ping occurred — local timestamp and date
    9:15am  •  Monday, July 22, 2024

  2. Ping Content
    recording or translation of the ping (in text), in whatever style is most useful for the recipient
    Learning is the future

  3. ID & Author
    sharing this ping’s place within the recipient’s more expansive “ping practice”
    Ping 188 of 322  •  Laurel Schwulst

*

Depending on where pings live or are recorded, they may appear differently—

By default, pings are internal, local to your inner world. That said, unless you publish a ping, your (author) name need not appear.

If you record pings with pen & paper, you may only have time to jot down the date. This can still be useful, so use whatever medium(s) best suit you.

Relatedly, you can use existing notes apps for pings, simply by using the word “ping.” Later on, after multiple pings have accumulated, searching for the word “ping” allows oneself to look through past pings.

I’ve been thinking about what it means to get a “ping from the universe,” and how that's a helpful metaphor for the whisper of intuition. Having that name is really helpful. Because when I get a good idea, I think to myself, “Oh, I know what that is. That's a ping from the universe.” And I can note it down.

— Laurel Schwulst

If you'd like to learn more about pings from a more elemental lens, feel free to visit our method.

Thank you for experiencing this transmission —
From: Laurel Schwulst & Peter Pelberg
